message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s elevated blood pressure, atrophy of limbs, and striae suggest Cushing’s syndrome. The best initial step in management is to perform a dexamethasone suppression test to confirm the diagnosis. Hydrochlorothiazide, metformin and MRI of the head are not appropriate initial management steps for Cushing’s syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs and symptoms of Cushing's syndrome, such as hypertension, atrophy of limbs, and striae on his abdomen. The best initial step in management is to perform a dexamethasone suppression test to confirm the diagnosis. Hydrochlorothiazide and metformin are medications used to treat hypertension and diabetes, respectively, but would not address the underlying cause. MRI of the head would not provide any useful information in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation suggests possible Cushing's syndrome, and the best initial step in management is a dexamethasone suppression test to confirm the diagnosis. Hydrochlorothiazide alone would not be enough to manage the patient's hypertension, and metformin would not be effective for managing hypertension. MRI of the head is not indicated at this point in the patient's management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s high blood pressure, atrophy of limbs, and striae on abdomen are signs of Cushing’s syndrome, which can be caused by excess glucocorticoids. Dexamethasone suppression test can help diagnose Cushing’s syndrome. Hydrochlorothiazide is a treatment for hypertension, but the cause of the hypertension needs to be addressed first. Metformin is a treatment for diabetes, which the patient also has, but it does not address the high blood pressure or potential Cushing’s syndrome. An MRI of the head is not indicated for the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Cushing's syndrome, which can cause hypertension, elevated blood glucose, and muscle atrophy. The best initial step in management is the dexamethasone suppression test to confirm the diagnosis. Hydrochlorothiazide is a medication used to treat hypertension, Metformin is used to manage blood glucose levels in diabetes, and an MRI of the head does not address the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hypertension and an elevated fasting blood glucose, which suggests the possibility of Cushing’s syndrome. The best initial step in management is to perform a dexamethasone suppression test to identify if there is an overproduction of cortisol. Hydrochlorothiazide is used to treat hypertension but not the underlying cause. Metformin is used to treat diabetes, which is a result of the underlying cause. MRI of the head is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of Cushing's syndrome due to the obesity, atrophy, and striae. The elevated blood pressure and glucose levels suggest that the cause may be cortisol-secreting adrenal adenoma. Therefore, the best initial step in management is to perform a dexamethasone suppression test to confirm the diagnosis. Hydrochlorothiazide may be used to treat hypertension but it will not address the underlying cause. Metformin is used to treat diabetes, but it will not address the underlying cause. An MRI of the head is not indicated for the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s hypertension, hyperglycemia, and physical exam findings are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome. The initial step in management would be to perform a dexamethasone suppression test to confirm the diagnosis. Options B and C are not appropriate as they do not address the underlying cause of the patient’s symptoms, and option D is not necessary without further evaluation to suggest a need for an MRI of the head.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of Cushing’s syndrome, which includes hypertension, elevated blood glucose, and atrophy of limbs with striae on the abdomen. A dexamethasone suppression test will help confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic used to treat hypertension, Metformin is used to treat elevated blood glucose, and an MRI of the head is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and elevated fasting blood glucose, and physical exam findings suggest Cushing's syndrome. The best initial step in management is a dexamethasone suppression test to confirm the diagnosis. Hydrochlorothiazide is a hypertension medication and metformin is a medication for diabetes, but neither addresses the underlying cause. An MRI of the head is not indicated in this case.
